newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Saudi settles most term naphtha sales to Asia.
newsitem.headline: Saudi settles most term naphtha sales to Asia.

text.p: Saudi Aramco has mostly settled term negotiations to sell naphtha to Asian customers for July 1997 to June 1998, traders said on Friday.
However, they said some companies declined to lift any naphtha from Saudi Arabian ports in protest at the high level of prices, they said.

The Middle East's biggest naphtha producer began negotiations in Singapore on May 12 to sell about three million tonnes of A-180 naphtha and between 1.2 and three million tonnes of full-range naphtha.
Traders said most of the volume has been sold but negotiations are set to linger as some companies test Aramco's resolve over price.
The sources said most buyers have agreed to pay a record premium of $17.00 per tonne over Saudi Aramco's formula for the ethylene-rich feedstock A-180, lifting from Ras Tanurah.
But buyers were reluctant to pay Aramco a target premium of $15 for low-paraffinic full-range material from Jubail and Rabigh ports, they said.

The current term contracts, for first half 1997, A-180 is priced at $6.50 and full-range at $5.50-$5.80.Saudi Aramco traditionally sells on a one year basis, but the price is reviewed after six months.
Japan's Idemitsu pulled out of the negotiations, declining the pay the high price, a company source said.
A source at Itochu Corp confirmed the Japanese trading house had dropped out of the talks also, in protest against the high price of the Jubail material.
But Japanese traders Marubeni Corp, Mitsui, Kanematsu Corp and India's Reliance have agreed to take a package of the two grades, traders said. --Singapore Newsroom (+65-870-3086)
With contribution from Kiyoshi Takenaka in Tokyo.
